content: The Secret To Becoming a Top Writer On Medium The lessons I learned to achieve "Top Writer" status In Creativity & Leadership (and no, I don't have 10’s of thousands of followers). Jon Brosio Blocked Unblock Follow Following May 23, 2018 Photo by Alice Achterhof on  Unsplash It almost feels like it was yesterday —  the day I discovered Medium. I was a bright-eyed and bushy-tailed writer who had been writing on his own blog for a handful of months. I wasn't making any [legitimate] progress in terms of expanding my influence and content. I would write up an article and post it live via my Squarespace site . I would then share the article via my personal Instagram account . Perhaps I'd get two scores of views whenever I'd share — perhaps less. It all happened to suddenly when I discovered Medium. I was perusing my Facebook feed and came across an article my former college professor Doan Winkel posted about a morning routine that would get one into a "peak state" fast all before 8am (can you guess the uber-successful Medium writer that published this?!) I was immediately smitten by the article and went down the rabbit - hole of this guy. I saw that he published all of his content on Medium. I then started to do my research on Medium (Below is Medium's about page if you've never taken a look… what a beautiful description): /about This was a place where "writers, thinkers, and storytellers bring you the smartest takes on topics that matter…" I thought I had found Valhalla. I could write about all the things that were buried deep down in my head that I knew I needed to share with the world and there would be people on the other side looking for this very content! I wouldn't have to cast fishing poles over the seas of the internet and hope that people would nibble and bite (like I was doing with my personal social media). Once I had found this place, I wasn't looking back. I wrote every day. My first article was nothing short of a joke. I had little clue as to what I was doing with this platform (hell, perhaps I still have little a clue). I saw the door crack open and I was going to make sure I put my shoulder down and burst the puppy wide open. So I kept of writing. My voice wasn't honed in. My structure was sporadic. My marketing was non-existent. My goal wasn't necessarily clear. But I knew this was the ticket. T he beautiful thing about Medium is the community that one can create around them. Here there were a bunch of people looking for the content I knew I needed to produce. More importantly, however, here were scores of writers sharing their success stories and offering strategies of what it takes to become a successful blogger. I absorbed all the lessons and anecdotes like a sponge. I had opened Pandora's box. I have been writing on Medium for just over a year now. Only until recently have I really made a push to further my influence on this platform and have it be a main focus for me. All the hard work is starting to pay off. I have seen a drastic increase in my views in the past few weeks. I have been awarded "Top Writer" status in Creativity. yay! I have been introduced to and collaborated with many different writers on this platform. I have been published in several different Medium publications. The lessons below are adopted from what I have learned from the people who helped forge the path before me, and some lessons I learned myself from falling over and picking myself up. Write until your hands hurt. When starting off, you probably aren't going to be that good. This isn't meant to bully you or put you down in any way. Unless you're some type of writing prodigy or have already a copious amount of experience content writing before you get serious about Medium, you are going to publish a lot of lackluster content. It's just the truth of the matter. How does one get better at writing? Well the best method is practice. When I first started out (and even still to this day) I write until my hands hurt. /2KGq9zB I'll write and article and then rewrite. I'll then let it sit for a bit and perhaps rewrite one more time. I'll then publish it and get back on to the next article. I know that not every article is going to be "solid-gold." Shit, I wouldn't even be surprised if I have yet to write anything that could be described as such. The most important part about blogging and content writing is that you get up to the plate and swing. “The most important thing about art is to work. Nothing else matters except sitting down every day and trying.” ― Steven Pressfield Practice creating killer headlines. You might have the best article in the world. In a crowded space like blogging, however, unless you incentivize the reader to actually click into your article, it will forever be lost to the deep, dark confines of the unread web. When I first started writing online, I remember I thought that if I made my title "artsy" or obliquely compelling that that would draw people in. ambiguity does nothing but drive people away. What are you trying to do with your articles? Above all, you should be trying to help your reader solve a certain problem, add value in someway, and educate on a topic your audience was once unaware of. Aimlessly talking about what is in your head won't get you anywhere. Furthermore, creating a headline that doesn't do anything to tempt or compel your reader to click will leave the article dormant. A great resource I use for generating headlines is Sumo's headline generator tool. The have spent countless hours accumulating the various headlines that have worked (and resulted in viral articles) throughout the internet. It's a really cool "plug-and-chug" tool that can be found on their website . Submit your work to Medium publications. This is probably the "Holy Grail" of getting your content more views and thus becoming a Top Writer. Again, like I stated in the title — I'm not someone on this platform with thousands if not tens of thousands of followers. There are so many people on Medium with a loyal following that it almost seems like they get "claps" and views because they have built that enormous following. So what kind of chance is left for us "little people." Thankfully, good content rules above all. If you practice your writing and start to create amazing content, you'll be rewarded for it. The rub here is actually getting the good content exposure. Medium publications is the key here. For months, whether it due to fear or perhaps my own ego, I refused to submit any work to Medium publications. Looking back now, it was definitely fear. When you submit to a publication you have the chance of it being rejected. When I self publish, I can always get it live. However, when you have the backing of their audience as well. Currently, I am a writer for The Ascent , The Startup and The Writing Cooperative . All of these publications have published a handful of my content (in just the last few weeks alone!) I was terrified the first time I submitted a story. I thought that if I submitted a story and they rejected it, it was the last time I'd have the opportunity to submit with them. I thought it was one and done. Wrong. (It's not a coincidence that I received my biggest spike when I got my work in the Medium publications.) If you strike out on the first at bat, get back up there and submit another. Again, good content rises above all. If you're content is strong and your headline rock solid, the publication will accept the stories and you can step into the fast-lane of exposure. I'll be the first to recognize that my numbers aren't the most impressive in the world. Far from it. I do see the impact that getting published within Medium helped my exposure drastically. I highly recommend working towards getting your work accepted in any of the publications that I mentioned above (or perhaps search for publications that are more geared towards your niche) . Always be scanning for the clues around you. When it comes to my writing, often times I have a pretty big ego. I've been working on silencing this deceitful voice for quite some time. Publishing often helps me stay humble. /2IXkrvW For a while I have been reading from P ersonal Development Gurus that one must be always focusing on output over input i.e. you must always be creating rather than scrolling your social media news feeds or binge watching Netflix. While I agree with that statement, I do think that input is vital to one's success creating. If you're going to absorb content, make sure it is rich and valuable content. There are thousands of articles on Medium, Quora and other blogs (I like Smartblogger, James Altucher 's blog, and Thoughtcatalogue just to name a few) that can offer you insight on how to take your game to the next level. Of course, just like everything, make sure you are absorbing and learning with a balance. It's so easy to open up a new tab on your browser and get lost in someone else's work for 4 hours. I truly believe in the Abundance Mentality (the idea that there is a copious amount of opportunity for all of us as opposed to the Scarcity Mentality that suggests there is a finite amount of opportunity and we need to eat one another in order to better ourselves). With that, there are hundreds of people — including myself — that are looking to help this community of doers, thinkers, writers, and dreamers rise up. The only way I can rise is if we all rise. If I didn't see it this way, why on Earth would I be writing this article? Shit, I'd be hoarding all of this information that actually worked only for myself. I wouldn't share this information if I didn't want it to work for you as well. That, for me, makes it all worth while. I know I'm not alone with this pursuit. So many of us want freedom. We want freedom from the rigmarole of the 9–5. We want freedom for our creativity. We want freedom in our speech and writing. We want financial freedom. We want freedom to travel and live where we want. I truly believe that together, we can all make that happen. Ready For A Boost? I’m Offering You a 6 Part Tested & Verified Guide Ripe With Powerful Concepts That Will Help You Identify, Project, Grow and Accomplish Your Creative Pursuit. >>>Get the FREE Guide here<<< Learned something? Hold down the 👏 to say “thanks!” and help others find this article. Also comment! What did you like? What did you hate? What are you working on? title_html: The Secret To Becoming a Top Writer On Medium
html:
Homepage
Homepage
Sign inGet started
  • About
  • Challenge
  • Write Now
  • Submit
  • Slack
  • Join

The Secret To Becoming a Top Writer On Medium

The lessons I learned to achieve "Top Writer" status In Creativity & Leadership (and no, I don't have 10’s of thousands of followers).

Jon Brosio
May 23, 2018

It almost feels like it was yesterday — the day I discovered Medium.

I was a bright-eyed and bushy-tailed writer who had been writing on his own blog for a handful of months.

I wasn't making any [legitimate] progress in terms of expanding my influence and content. I would write up an article and post it live via my Squarespace site. I would then share the article via my personal Instagram account.

Perhaps I'd get two scores of views whenever I'd share — perhaps less.

It all happened to suddenly when I discovered Medium. I was perusing my Facebook feed and came across an article my former college professor Doan Winkel posted about a morning routine that would get one into a "peak state" fast all before 8am (can you guess the uber-successful Medium writer that published this?!)

I was immediately smitten by the article and went down the rabbit-hole of this guy.

I saw that he published all of his content on Medium.

I then started to do my research on Medium (Below is Medium's about page if you've never taken a look… what a beautiful description):

This was a place where "writers, thinkers, and storytellers bring you the smartest takes on topics that matter…"

I thought I had found Valhalla.

I could write about all the things that were buried deep down in my head that I knew I needed to share with the world and there would be people on the other side looking for this very content!

I wouldn't have to cast fishing poles over the seas of the internet and hope that people would nibble and bite (like I was doing with my personal social media).

Once I had found this place, I wasn't looking back.

I wrote every day.

My first article was nothing short of a joke. I had little clue as to what I was doing with this platform (hell, perhaps I still have little a clue).

I saw the door crack open and I was going to make sure I put my shoulder down and burst the puppy wide open.

So I kept of writing.

  • My voice wasn't honed in.
  • My structure was sporadic.
  • My marketing was non-existent.
  • My goal wasn't necessarily clear.

But I knew this was the ticket.

The beautiful thing about Medium is the community that one can create around them.

Here there were a bunch of people looking for the content I knew I needed to produce.

More importantly, however, here were scores of writers sharing their success stories and offering strategies of what it takes to become a successful blogger.

I absorbed all the lessons and anecdotes like a sponge.

I had opened Pandora's box.

I have been writing on Medium for just over a year now. Only until recently have I really made a push to further my influence on this platform and have it be a main focus for me.

All the hard work is starting to pay off.

  • I have seen a drastic increase in my views in the past few weeks.
  • I have been awarded "Top Writer" status in Creativity.
  • I have been introduced to and collaborated with many different writers on this platform.
  • I have been published in several different Medium publications.

The lessons below are adopted from what I have learned from the people who helped forge the path before me, and some lessons I learned myself from falling over and picking myself up.

Write until your hands hurt.

When starting off, you probably aren't going to be that good.

This isn't meant to bully you or put you down in any way.

Unless you're some type of writing prodigy or have already a copious amount of experience content writing before you get serious about Medium, you are going to publish a lot of lackluster content.

It's just the truth of the matter.

How does one get better at writing? Well the best method is practice. When I first started out (and even still to this day) I write until my hands hurt.

I'll write and article and then rewrite. I'll then let it sit for a bit and perhaps rewrite one more time. I'll then publish it and get back on to the next article.

I know that not every article is going to be "solid-gold." Shit, I wouldn't even be surprised if I have yet to write anything that could be described as such.

The most important part about blogging and content writing is that you get up to the plate and swing.

“The most important thing about art is to work. Nothing else matters except sitting down every day and trying.” ― Steven Pressfield

Practice creating killer headlines.

You might have the best article in the world.

In a crowded space like blogging, however, unless you incentivize the reader to actually click into your article, it will forever be lost to the deep, dark confines of the unread web.

When I first started writing online, I remember I thought that if I made my title "artsy" or obliquely compelling that that would draw people in.

ambiguity does nothing but drive people away.

What are you trying to do with your articles?

Above all, you should be trying to help your reader solve a certain problem, add value in someway, and educate on a topic your audience was once unaware of.

Aimlessly talking about what is in your head won't get you anywhere.

Furthermore, creating a headline that doesn't do anything to tempt or compel your reader to click will leave the article dormant.

A great resource I use for generating headlines is Sumo's headline generator tool. The have spent countless hours accumulating the various headlines that have worked (and resulted in viral articles) throughout the internet.

It's a really cool "plug-and-chug" tool that can be found on their website.

Submit your work to Medium publications.

This is probably the "Holy Grail" of getting your content more views and thus becoming a Top Writer.

Again, like I stated in the title — I'm not someone on this platform with thousands if not tens of thousands of followers. There are so many people on Medium with a loyal following that it almost seems like they get "claps" and views because they have built that enormous following.

So what kind of chance is left for us "little people."

Thankfully, good content rules above all.

If you practice your writing and start to create amazing content, you'll be rewarded for it.

The rub here is actually getting the good content exposure.

Medium publications is the key here.

For months, whether it due to fear or perhaps my own ego, I refused to submit any work to Medium publications. Looking back now, it was definitely fear.

When you submit to a publication you have the chance of it being rejected. When I self publish, I can always get it live.

However, when you have the backing of their audience as well.

Currently, I am a writer for The Ascent, The Startup and The Writing Cooperative. All of these publications have published a handful of my content (in just the last few weeks alone!)

I was terrified the first time I submitted a story. I thought that if I submitted a story and they rejected it, it was the last time I'd have the opportunity to submit with them. I thought it was one and done.

Wrong.

If you strike out on the first at bat, get back up there and submit another. Again, good content rises above all. If you're content is strong and your headline rock solid, the publication will accept the stories and you can step into the fast-lane of exposure.

I'll be the first to recognize that my numbers aren't the most impressive in the world. Far from it.

I do see the impact that getting published within Medium helped my exposure drastically.

I highly recommend working towards getting your work accepted in any of the publications that I mentioned above (or perhaps search for publications that are more geared towards your niche).

Always be scanning for the clues around you.

When it comes to my writing, often times I have a pretty big ego. I've been working on silencing this deceitful voice for quite some time. Publishing often helps me stay humble.

For a while I have been reading from Personal Development Gurus that one must be always focusing on output over input i.e. you must always be creating rather than scrolling your social media news feeds or binge watching Netflix.

While I agree with that statement, I do think that input is vital to one's success creating.

If you're going to absorb content, make sure it is rich and valuable content. There are thousands of articles on Medium, Quora and other blogs (I like Smartblogger, James Altucher's blog, and Thoughtcatalogue just to name a few) that can offer you insight on how to take your game to the next level.

Of course, just like everything, make sure you are absorbing and learning with a balance.

It's so easy to open up a new tab on your browser and get lost in someone else's work for 4 hours.

I truly believe in the Abundance Mentality (the idea that there is a copious amount of opportunity for all of us as opposed to the Scarcity Mentality that suggests there is a finite amount of opportunity and we need to eat one another in order to better ourselves).

With that, there are hundreds of people — including myself — that are looking to help this community of doers, thinkers, writers, and dreamers rise up.

The only way I can rise is if we all rise.

If I didn't see it this way, why on Earth would I be writing this article?

Shit, I'd be hoarding all of this information that actually worked only for myself.

I wouldn't share this information if I didn't want it to work for you as well.

That, for me, makes it all worth while.

I know I'm not alone with this pursuit. So many of us want freedom.

  • We want freedom from the rigmarole of the 9–5.
  • We want freedom for our creativity.
  • We want freedom in our speech and writing.
  • We want financial freedom.
  • We want freedom to travel and live where we want.

I truly believe that together, we can all make that happen.

Ready For A Boost?

I’m Offering You a 6 Part Tested & Verified Guide Ripe With Powerful Concepts That Will Help You Identify, Project, Grow and Accomplish Your Creative Pursuit.

>>>Get the FREE Guide here<<<

Learned something? Hold down the 👏 to say “thanks!” and help others find this article.

Also comment! What did you like? What did you hate? What are you working on?

title: The Secret To Becoming a Top Writer On Medium
content_html:

The lessons I learned to achieve "Top Writer" status In Creativity & Leadership (and no, I don't have 10’s of thousands of followers).

May 23, 2018
